column4: Online demand fuels Abercrombie & Fitch profit beat, rosy sales outlook
column5: (Reuters) - Abercrombie & Fitch Co forecast first-quarter net sales above estimates on Tuesday after tightened costs and surging online sales of sweaters, fleece tops and knit bottoms helped it report a better-than-expected quarterly profit.
column6: The company, which said it would resume share buybacks, also benefited from increased prices during the holidays as it reined in promotions and tightened inventory.
column7: The teen- and millenial-focused retailer has partnered with TikTok influencers Charli and Dixie D’Amelio and ramped up investments in its online business to combat declining store traffic as customers shift to online shopping due to the pandemic.
column8: It projected a 30% to 40% increase in net sales in the first quarter versus an average analysts’ estimate for a 32.8% jump to $644.62 million.
column9: Demand for its loungewear and Gilly Hicks brand’s activewear drove digital sales 34% higher, as customers staying at home turned to comfortable clothing.
column10: “Our distribution centers remained operational, enabling us to fulfill digital customer demand globally, partially mitigating lost sales from temporary store closures,” said Chief Executive Officer Fran Horowitz.
column11: Net sales fell 5% during the quarter.
column12: In a bid to rein in costs, the Ohio-based company reduced payroll expenses, suspended dividend and closed 137 stores last year, including eight larger format flagships, as it pivots toward smaller, newly remodeled stores to draw in customers.
column13: Excluding one-time items, the company reported a profit of $1.50 per share in the fourth quarter, beating analysts’ average estimate of $1.22 per share.

column4: Abercrombie & Fitch quarterly sales fall 5%
column5: Abercrombie & Fitch Co (ANF.N) forecast first-quarter net sales above estimates on Tuesday after tightened costs and surging online sales of sweaters, fleece tops and knit bottoms helped it report a better-than-expected quarterly profit.
column6: The company, which said it would resume share buybacks, also benefited from increased prices during the holidays as it reined in promotions and tightened inventory.
column7: The teen- and millenial-focused retailer has partnered with TikTok influencers Charli and Dixie D'Amelio and ramped up investments in its online business to combat declining store traffic as customers shift to online shopping due to the pandemic.
column8: It projected a 30% to 40% increase in net sales in the first quarter versus an average analysts' estimate for a 32.8% jump to $644.62 million.
column9: Demand for its loungewear and Gilly Hicks brand's activewear drove digital sales 34% higher, as customers staying at home turned to comfortable clothing.
column10: "Our distribution centers remained operational, enabling us to fulfill digital customer demand globally, partially mitigating lost sales from temporary store closures," said Chief Executive Officer Fran Horowitz.
column11: Net sales fell 5% during the quarter.
column12: In a bid to rein in costs, the Ohio-based company reduced payroll expenses, suspended dividend and closed 137 stores last year, including eight larger format flagships, as it pivots toward smaller, newly remodeled stores to draw in customers.
column13: Excluding one-time items, the company reported a profit of $1.50 per share in the fourth quarter, beating analysts' average estimate of $1.22 per share.

column4: Abercrombie sees smaller decline in holiday-quarter sales
column5: (Reuters) - Apparel retailer Abercrombie & Fitch Co on Monday forecast holiday-quarter net sales to decline between 5% and 7%, as strong online demand was not enough to cushion the blow from temporary store closures and COVID-19 restrictions.
column6: The company, which owns the Hollister apparel brand, had previously estimated net sales to decline between 5% and 10% for the quarter, with analysts expecting a 5.5% fall, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.
column7: Abercrombie also said it expected fourth-quarter gross profit rate to be up at least 130 basis points, compared to last year’s 58.2%, as it discounted less.
column8: Online demand for activewear and loungewear has soared since the start of the lockdowns, but in-store sales have taken a hit as a resurgence in COVID-19 cases in North America and major European markets forced governments to reintroduce certain restrictions.
column9: Abercrombie’s shares rose about 1% to $23.34 in extended trading.

column4: Abercrombie forecasts muted holiday quarter as COVID-19 cases rise
column5: (Reuters) -Abercrombie & Fitch Co gave a tepid forecast for the crucial holiday quarter on Tuesday, as a resurgence in COVID-19 cases could dampen consumer appetite to shop ahead of the busy season.
column6: Shares of the apparel retailer reversed course to trade down about 2% after touching their highest in over a year as the company handily beat expectations for third quarter results.
column7: “With COVID numbers rising, there is the potential for a change in apparel demand and customer willingness to enter physical stores. Also, there is a looming possibility of renewed store restrictions and closures.” Chief Financial Officer Scott Lipesky said on a post-earnings call with analysts.
column8: A surge in cases has already spurred Britain and other countries in Europe, as well as many American states, to go into another lockdown.
column9: Abercrombie now forecasts holiday quarter sales to be down between 5% and 10%, in line with analysts’ expectations of a decline of 7.35% to $1.097 billion.
column10: The company also anticipates markdown pressures as it exits from seven of its flagship locations in a move to reduce its dependence on demand from tourists that has taken a hit due to the pandemic.
column11: Apparel retailers have been ramping up investments in their online business to combat declining store traffic as customers shift to online shopping due to the pandemic, tapping popular social media influencers and adding options such as curbside pickups.
column12: Abercrombie’s digital sales, which jumped 43% in the third quarter, were also boosted by demand for its Gilly Hicks brand’s activewear and loungewear as customers staying at home turn to comfortable clothing.
column13: Excluding one-time items, the company reported a profit of 76 cents per share in the quarter ended Oct. 31, compared with expectations of break-even, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.
column14: Net sales fell 5% to $819.7 million, but beat estimates of $739.36 million.

column4: Abercrombie quarterly sales beat Wall Street estimates
column5: Nov 24 (Reuters) - Abercrombie & Fitch Co’s quarterly sales beat Wall Street expectations on Tuesday, as consumers working or attending classes from home due to the COVID-19 pandemic shopped online for the retailer’s apparel.
column6: Net sales fell to $819.7 million in the third quarter ended Oct. 31, from $863.5 million a year ago, but beat analysts’ average estimate of $739.36 million, according to Refinitiv IBES data. (Reporting by Aditi Sebastian; Editing by Shailesh Kuber)

column4: Coach parent names interim CEO Crevoiserat to top job
column5: (Reuters) - Coach handbag maker Tapestry Inc TPR.N said on Tuesday its interim Chief Executive Officer Joanne Crevoiserat would permanently transition to the top job.
column6: She was the chief financial officer until July and replaced CEO Jide Zeitlin who stepped down amid an investigation into his personal behavior.
column7: Crevoiserat, a former executive at Abercrombie & Fitch Co ANF.N and Kohl's Corp KSS.N, is the first woman to lead the company since it went public in 2000 under the Coach Inc guise.
column8: She takes over at a time when the luxury goods industry is facing weak demand due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Tapestry is expected to report its first-quarter financial results later this week.
column9: The company said Crevoiserat is expected to be appointed to Tapestry’s board.

column4: Abercrombie & Fitch posts surprise profit on lower costs, online boost
column5: (Reuters) - Abercrombie & Fitch Co ANF.N reported a surprise profit on Thursday as the apparel retailer slashed costs and benefited from a surge in online orders during the COVID-19 pandemic, sending its shares up as much as 17%.
column6: The company has been ramping up investments in its online platforms to cushion the hit from coronavirus-induced restrictions, and has also partnered with TikTok Stars Charli and Dixie D’Amelio in an effort to attract younger shoppers.
column7: Digital sales jumped 56% in the second quarter, helped by higher demand for Abercrombie’s Gilly Hicks brand’s activewear range, as well as its loungewear, as stuck-at-home customers opted for more comfortable clothing.
column8: The company, which has furloughed employees, halted share buybacks and cut executive salaries to reduce costs, said store and distribution expenses were down nearly 18%, while marketing costs fell 16%.
column9: Excluding items, Abercrombie earned a profit of 23 cents per share in the second quarter, while analysts were expecting a loss of 83 cents per share, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.
column10: Net sales fell 17% to $698.3 million in the three months ended Aug. 1, but beat estimates of $658.44 million.
column11: The company forecast a bigger-than-expected 15% to 20% drop in current-quarter sales, as the pandemic hampers its efforts to boost traffic through a revamped denim line and remodeled stores after past fashion missteps.
column12: Abercrombie executives said on a call with analysts the company would still manage expenses, assuming that the sales trend would not improve, adding that there would more would be more promotional discounts in the holiday quarter.

column4: Abercrombie & Fitch Co quarterly sales beat expectations on online boost
column5: Aug 27 (Reuters) - Abercrombie & Fitch Co reported better-than-expected quarterly sales on Thursday as the apparel retailer benefited from a surge in online orders during the COVID-19 pandemic.
column6: Net income attributable to the company was $5.5 million, or 9 cents per share, compared with a loss of $31.1 million, or 48 cents per share, a year earlier. The year-ago quarter included flagship store exit charges of about $45 million.
column7: Net sales fell to $698.3 million in the second quarter ended Aug. 1, but beat the average expectation of $658.44 million, according to Refinitiv IBES data.

column4: UPDATE 2-Abercrombie & Fitch posts steeper-than-expected loss as pandemic keeps stores shut
column5: (Adds details from conference call, updates share movement)
column6: May 28 (Reuters) - Abercrombie & Fitch Co reported a steeper-than-expected quarterly loss on Thursday, hurt by plunging demand for apparel as most of its stores were forced to shutter to curb the spread of the novel coronavirus, sending the retailer’s shares down as much as 10%.
column7: The temporary closures of its recently remodeled stores have slowed Abercrombie’s efforts to revive its struggling flagship clothing brand, hurt by past fashion missteps. The crisis also hampered growth at Hollister.
column8: A wide slate of retailers, who were already struggling with online competition, have also borne the brunt of financial pain due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with many being forced into bankruptcy.
column9: “(We are) trying to understand what the new normal is, because there is certainly nothing like the old normal, with reduced footfall in the stores, whether it’s from demand or limiting the amount of people in the stores,” Chief Financial Officer Scott Lipesky said on a post-earnings call.
column10: Abercrombie said it was not providing a detailed forecast for the second quarter or the full year, but added that sales at its reopened stores in the United States and EMEA regions were at about 80% and 60%, respectively, of what they were a year-ago.
column11: The only bright spot in the quarter was Abercrombie’s digital sales that rose 25% as online shoppers bought more loungewear, knits and joggers as well as Gilly Hicks’ new activewear while they stayed at home.
column12: Net sales fell 34% to $485.4 million in the first quarter ended May 2, its biggest drop in over a decade, missing expectations of $497.3 million, according to Refinitiv Eikon data.
column13: Net loss attributable to the company widened to $244.2 million, from $19.2 million a year earlier, hit by impairments and tax-related charges.
column14: Excluding one-time items, the company reported a loss of $3.29 per share, wider than analysts’ expectations of a loss of $1.39 per share. (Reporting by Aditi Sebastian; Editing by Shailesh Kuber and Rashmi Aich)

column4: Abercrombie & Fitch quarterly loss widens, sales fall 34% on pandemic woes
column5: May 28 (Reuters) - Abercrombie & Fitch Co reported a 34% fall in quarterly sales and posted a wider loss on Thursday, as the apparel retailer was forced to close stores in markets around the world due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
column6: Net sales fell to $485.4 million from $734 million, for the first quarter ended May 2, while net loss attributable to the company widened to $244.2 million, or $3.90 per share, from $19.2 million, or 29 cents per share, a year earlier. (Reporting by Aditi Sebastian; Editing by Shailesh Kuber)

column4: Abercrombie, Gap prepare to reopen stores as lockdowns ease
column5: (Reuters) - Abercrombie & Fitch Co ANF.N and cash-strapped Gap Inc GPS.N on Wednesday laid out plans to reopen stores in areas where lockdown curbs have eased, while also introducing social-distancing measures.
column6: Retailers are trying to restart business activity brought to a standstill due to the COVID-19 lockdowns. Their stores have remained closed for weeks and have resulted in thousands of workers being laid off or furloughed.
column7: Several U.S. states, led by Texas and Georgia, have begun a phased reopening of businesses as they look to restart their economies, but health experts have warned lifting restrictions too quickly could spark a new wave of infections.
column8: Gap, which had warned it may not survive the next 12 months, said it would open a few stores in Texas this weekend. It aims to reopen up to 800 stores across brands such as Old Navy, Gap and Banana Republic by the end of May. (bit.ly/3dnHUCd)
column9: The company said it would be temporarily closing fitting rooms and restrooms at stores that will be operating with reduced hours, while encouraging shoppers to wear face coverings and maintain distance from one another.
column10: Abercrombie too has started reopening stores, but did not provide the number of outlets or their specific locations. Macy's Inc M.N and Coach owner Tapestry Inc TPR.N have also begun reopening stores in the United States.

column4: Abercrombie & Fitch begins store reopenings as lockdowns ease
column5: May 6 (Reuters) - Abercrombie & Fitch Co has begun reopening stores in parts of the world where lockdown restrictions have eased, the company said on Wednesday, as more retailers chart out paths to recovery after the COVID-19 pandemic upended businesses.
column6: Abercrombie closed all its stores in North America, Europe and the Middle East in mid-March as government lockdowns to control the virus spread brought business activities to a near standstill. In a letter posted on the company's blog, Chief Executive Officer Fran Horowitz said select stores were opening on a rolling basis. The letter did not mention the number of stores that have been reopened or their specific locations. (bit.ly/2W8pgsh)
column7: Macy’s Inc and Coach owner Tapestry Inc have also begun reopening their stores in the United States.
column8: Multiple U.S. states have begun a phased reopening of businesses as they look to restart their economies, but health experts have expressed concern that lifting restrictions too quickly could spark a new wave of infections. (Reporting by Uday Sampath in Bengaluru; Editing by Shounak Dasgupta)

column4: BRIEF-Abercrombie & Fitch Co Says CEO Fran Horowitz's FY 2019 Compensation $8.4 Mln Versus $8.5 Mln In FY 2018
column5: April 7 (Reuters) - Abercrombie & Fitch Co:
column6: * ABERCROMBIE & FITCH CO SAYS CEO FRAN HOROWITZ’S FY 2019 TOTAL COMPENSATION WAS $8.4 MILLION VERSUS $8.5 MILLION IN FY 2018 - SEC FILING
column7: * ABERCROMBIE & FITCH CO SAYS FOR 2019, CEO PAY RATIO WAS 4,293 TO 1 Source text for Eikon: [ID:bit.ly/3aPk80Y] Further company coverage:

column4: BRIEF-Abercrombie & Fitch Says Furloughing North America And EMEA Region Store Associates Beginning April 12
column5: April 6 (Reuters) - Abercrombie & Fitch Co:
column6: * ABERCROMBIE & FITCH CO. PROVIDES ADDITIONAL COVID-19-RELATED BUSINESS UPDATE
column7: * ABERCROMBIE & FITCH CO - COMPANY’S ONLINE STORES REMAIN OPEN GLOBALLY, AND MAJORITY OF STORES IN APAC REGION ARE OPEN
column8: * ABERCROMBIE & FITCH CO - IN NORTH AMERICA AND EMEA REGION, STORES REMAIN CLOSED
column9: * ABERCROMBIE & FITCH CO - CURRENT ENVIRONMENT HAS RESULTED IN SIGNIFICANTLY REDUCED DEMAND, REQUIRING FEWER RESOURCES TO SUPPORT BUSINESS
column10: * ABERCROMBIE & FITCH CO - FURLOUGHING ITS NORTH AMERICA AND EMEA REGION STORE ASSOCIATES BEGINNING APRIL 12
column11: * ABERCROMBIE & FITCH - IMPLEMENTING TEMPORARY REDUCTION IN WORK SCHEDULE, CORRESPONDING REDUCTION IN PAY FOR ABOUT 15% OF CORPORATE ASSOCIATES GLOBALLY
column12: * ABERCROMBIE & FITCH CO - TEMPORARY REDUCTIONS IN ITS LEADERSHIP TEAM’S SALARIES RANGING FROM 10% TO 33%
column13: * ABERCROMBIE & FITCH - REDUCTIONS IN ITS LEADERSHIP TEAM’S SALARIES FROM VICE PRESIDENT LEVEL UPWARDS, INCLUDING ALL NAMED EXECUTIVE OFFICERS AND CEO
column14: * ABERCROMBIE & FITCH CO - BOARD OF DIRECTORS’ CASH RETAINER WILL ALSO TEMPORARILY BE REDUCED BY 50%
column15: * ABERCROMBIE & FITCH CO - HAS CANCELLED ALL SPRING MERIT RAISES AND PROMOTIONS Source text for Eikon: Further company coverage:

column4: BRIEF-Abercrombie & Fitch Co. Provides COVID-19-Related Business Update
column5: March 26 (Reuters) - Abercrombie & Fitch Co:
column6: * ABERCROMBIE & FITCH CO. PROVIDES COVID-19-RELATED BUSINESS UPDATE
column7: * ABERCROMBIE & FITCH CO - WILL CONTINUE TO KEEP STORES OUTSIDE OF APAC REGION TEMPORARILY CLOSED UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE
column8: * ABERCROMBIE & FITCH CO - CONTINUE TO FOLLOW GUIDANCE TO DETERMINE WHEN IT CAN REOPEN STORES ACROSS NORTH AMERICA AND EMEA REGION
column9: * ABERCROMBIE & FITCH CO - STORES IN APAC REGION ACROSS ALL ITS BRANDS ARE CURRENTLY OPEN
column10: * ABERCROMBIE & FITCH CO - WILL NOT UNDERTAKE ANY SHARE BUYBACKS FOR FORESEEABLE FUTURE
column11: * ABERCROMBIE & FITCH - ON MARCH 25, INITIATED PROCESS TO BORROW $210 MILLION UNDER SENIOR SECURED ASSET-BASED REVOLVING CREDIT FACILITY Source text for Eikon: Further company coverage:

column4: Remodeled, smaller stores help Abercrombie holiday sales top expectations
column5: (Reuters) - Abercrombie & Fitch Co ANF.N beat quarterly sales and profit estimates on Wednesday as its new, smaller stores attracted more shoppers looking for jeans and women's dresses in the holiday season, sending its shares up 6% in early trading.
column6: As mall traffic across the United States take a hit from online shopping, the apparel maker has had to either shut or downsize dozens of its sprawling flagship stores and instead focus on opening cost-efficient smaller shops and pop-ups.
column7: Sales for the company, which draws 70% of its revenue from its stores, has been improving as it remodels stores with brighter interiors and larger fitting rooms in a bid to distance itself from its out-of-fashion risqué image from the 2000s.
column8: “Abercrombie stores were just outdated. They were dark, loud and the fragrance was all over the place,” Gabriella Santaniello, founder of retail research firm A-Line Partners, said.
column9: “The new store format is a much more modern representation of the brand and draws the customer’s attention to products.”
column10: Same-store sales for the Abercrombie brand rose 8% in the fourth quarter, exceeding estimates of a 3.3% increase, according to Refinitiv data.
column11: Same-store sales in the United States rose 3%, but it fell by the same measure internationally as the remodeling of Hollister stores outside the country has been slow.
column12: The coronavirus outbreak is set to add further pain to its international business, as the company forecast a hit of up to $80 million to its annual revenue due to the epidemic.
column13: Chief Financial Officer Scott Lipesky said the rapidly spreading virus had caused some temporary store closures outside the Asia-Pacific region and weak traffic in tourist heavy destinations.
column14: It forecast fiscal 2020 net sales growth of flat to 2%, while analysts expected a 1.6% rise.
column15: The company’s fourth-quarter net sales rose 2.5% to $1.18 billion, beating estimates of $1.17 billion.
column16: Net income attributable to the company dropped to $83.1 million, or $1.29 per share, from $96.94 million, or $1.42 per share, a year earlier.
column17: Excluding certain items, it earned $1.31 per share, beating expectations of $1.23.

column4: Abercrombie & Fitch's quarterly same-store sales beat, warns of virus impact
column5: March 4 (Reuters) - Abercrombie & Fitch Co beat quarterly same-store sales estimates on Wednesday, boosted by strong demand for its flagship clothing brand in the holiday season.
column6: Sales at established stores rose 1% in the fourth quarter ended Feb. 1, while analysts on average had expected a climb of 0.7%, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.
column7: The retailer said it expects a hit of up to $80 million to its annual revenue due to the coronavirus outbreak and forecasts fiscal 2020 net sales growth of flat to 2%, while analysts expected a rise of 1.6%. (Reporting by Uday Sampath in Bengaluru; Editing by Sherry Jacob-Phillips)

column4: Abercrombie & Fitch trims forecast as Hollister, international business drag
column5: (Reuters) - Teen apparel retailer Abercrombie & Fitch Co ANF.N trimmed its annual sales growth forecast on Tuesday, blaming political issues ranging from Brexit to Hong Kong protests for keeping customers away from its stores outside the United States.
column6: Shares fell as much as 8% after the company also reported its first same-store sales drop in at least eight quarters at Hollister, a brand that has powered much of the retailer’s growth.
column7: Abercrombie joins a growing list of American retailers that have called out months of pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong for causing store closures and hurting revenue from the Asian shopping hub.
column8: The company, which earns about 32% of its revenue from international markets, also said on a conference call that protests in Spain and France, as well as uncertainty around how Britain leaves the European Union, dampened demand in Europe.
column9: The Ohio-based company said it now expects net sales to be in the range of flat to up 1% for the full year, compared with a previous range of flat to up 2%.
column10: Abercrombie has in the past relied on Hollister to generate the bulk of its revenue with its denim and Gilly Hicks lingerie collections, but the surfwear-themed brand is no longer attracting as much demand from younger customers.
column11: “Their fashion was a little bit off course for their customer” said Gabriella Santaniello, founder of retail research firm A-Line Partners.
column12: “Hollister was sort of their golden child ... (so) the reversal in the sales trends there is a bit concerning.”
column13: Same-store sales at Hollister dropped 2% in the quarter, while analysts on average had estimated a 0.20% rise, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.
column14: Sluggish demand for Hollister offset a 3% rise in comparable stores sales at Abercrombie unit, while international comparable sales fell 8%.
column15: The company also said U.S. tariffs on Chinese imports are expected to impact merchandise cost and gross profit by about $4 million in the fourth quarter and about $5 million in the full year.
column16: The teen apparel maker said the current forecast assumes 16% of goods will be made in China, down from about 25% in fiscal 2018.
column17: Net income attributable to the company fell to $6.5 million from $23.9 million a year earlier.
column18: Excluding items, the company earned 23 cents per share, narrowly missing analysts’ estimate of 24 cents.
column19: Net sales rose marginally to $863.5 million, but also missed Wall Street estimates.

column4: Abercrombie & Fitch misses same-store sales estimates
column5: Nov 26 (Reuters) - Abercrombie & Fitch Co fell short of quarterly same-store sales estimates on Tuesday, hit by sluggish demand for the teen apparel retailer’s surfwear-themed Hollister clothing line.
column6: Sales at established stores were flat in the third quarter ended Nov. 2, while analysts on average had expected a 0.30% rise, according to IBES data from Refinitiv. Net income attributable to the company fell to $6.5 million, or 10 cents per share, from $23.9 million, or 35 cents per share, a year earlier. (Reporting by Aditi Sebastian; Editing by Sriraj Kalluvila)

column4: BUZZ--Street view: Choppy Q2 ahead for Abercrombie & Fitch
column5: May 30 (Reuters) - ** Apparel retailer Abercrombie & Fitch Co on Wednesday forecast second-quarter sales below estimates, amid slowing demand for Hollister, a brand that has fuelled company growth over the last two years
column6: ** At least four brokerages cut their PT following results
column7: ** Shares dropped 25% on Wednesday
column8: ** Jefferies (“hold,” PT: $20) says co’s progress remains choppy and Q1 was overshadowed by soft Q2 guidance
column9: ** “While we are encouraged by actions taken to reduce the headwind from underperforming stores, the decel. into Q2 and increased reliance on H2 to meet the FY guide gives us pause,” - Jefferies
column10: ** Wedbush (“underperform,” PT: $16) says current trends reflected in proprietary data show deteriorating weekly cadence in May, and not seeing signs of improvement at Abercrombie or Hollister
column11: ** Wedbush says even the guidance that sorely missed investor expectations is at risk, compounded by continued uncertainty around tariff increases not reflected in new guidance
column12: ** RBC (“sector perform,” PT: $22) says choppy May start suggests co is currently running below Q2’s flat guidance
column13: ** B.Riley (“Neutral,” PT: $24) says Hollister slows due to weaker Asia performance
column14: ** Expects Q2 top-line to be flat to +2% YOY, while SSS should be flat (Reporting by Adil Bhat in Bengaluru)

column4: Abercrombie & Fitch shares plummet 25% on sluggish Hollister demand
column5: (Reuters) - Abercrombie & Fitch Co’s shares fell 25% on Wednesday after the apparel company forecast second-quarter sales below estimates amid slowing demand for Hollister, a brand that has fueled company growth over the last two years.
column6: The company also said it would close three flagship stores, including a Hollister store in SoHo, New York City, incurring about $45 million of lease-related charges in the second quarter.
column7: Surf-themed Hollister has been a bright spot for the company as its casual and fun apparel gained popularity among young shoppers, who had previously abandoned flagship brand, Abercrombie, after its logo-emblazoned tees fell out of fashion.
column8: However, the company’s most recent results showed that demand for Hollister was slowing, with its same-store sales rising just 2% in the quarter ended May 4, missing the average analyst estimate of a 3.3% increase, according to Refinitiv IBES data.
column9: A year ago, Hollister’s quarterly same-store sales rose 6%.
column10: For an interactive graphic, click here: tmsnrt.rs/2YWPs7H
column11: “Expectations were really high for Hollister, that has been their shining star ... (So) Hollister’s numbers falling short and potentially slowing, is a red flag for investors,” Gabriela Santaniello, analyst at A line Partners, said.
column12: Chief Executive Officer Fran Horowitz said fashion missteps at Hollister in Asia and the company’s failure to not take full advantage of major promotional events on platforms such as China’s Tmall hurt international sales, which fell 6%.
column13: Overall same-store sales in the first quarter rose 1%, below estimates of a 1.33% increase, while net sales rose marginally to $734 million.
column14: Abercrombie forecast second-quarter net sales to be flat to up 2%, below estimates of a 2.8% increase. The company blamed its disappointing forecast on a $10 million hit from a stronger dollar, but said the outlook did not include the impact of new tariffs the United States may impose on Chinese goods.
column15: Last financial year, about 25% of Abercrombie’s globally sourced merchandise was imported from China, but Horowitz said the company was working to bring that down to 20% this year.
column16: Company executives also flagged slowing U.S. mall traffic and a more competitive retail landscape as a sales dampener for both Hollister and Abercrombie going into the second quarter.
column17: Net loss attributable to the company narrowed to $19.12 million in the reported quarter, or 29 cents per share, from $42.5 million, or 62 cents per share, a year earlier.
column18: Analysts had expected a loss of 43 cents per share on net sales of $733.4 million.
column19: Shares of the company were down 24% at $19.01 and on course for their worst day in nearly two decades.

column4: Abercrombie & Fitch misses quarterly same-store sales estimates
column5: May 29 (Reuters) - Abercrombie & Fitch Co missed Wall Street estimates for quarterly same-store sales on Wednesday, hurt by slowing demand for its surf-themed Hollister apparel.
column6: Same-store sales in the first quarter ended May 4 rose 1%, below analysts’ average estimate of a 1.33% increase, according to Refinitiv IBES data.
column7: Net sales rose to $734 million from $730.9 million. Analysts had expected net sales of $733.4 million. (Reporting by Uday Sampath in Bengaluru; Editing by Shinjini Ganguli)

column4: Florida high school, scene of massacre, wins prize to help fund senior prom
column5: (Reuters) - Florida’s Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School, scene of one of the country’s worst mass shootings, has won the $150,000 grand prize in a national contest sponsored by a popular clothing line to fund entertainment at the school’s senior prom.
column6: Hollister, which is owned by Abercrombie & Fitch Co, said on Tuesday that the Parkland, Florida, school has won its Prom X Hollister Contest. The prize money can be spent on booking a musical artist for its prom, according to the contest’s rules.
column7: Stoneman Douglas, whose prom is scheduled for May 11, made national headlines on Feb. 14, 2018, when a gunman fatally shot 17 students and staff at the high school.
column8: Stoneman Douglas garnered more than a quarter of all votes cast for the top 10 high schools nominated for this year’s contest, Abercrombie & Fitch said in an email.
column9: “We could not think of a more deserving school to win our inaugural prom contest,” the company said. “The response from the Parkland community and its supporters was incredible.”
column10: The Broward County School Board was to consider accepting the prize at a meeting scheduled earlier on Tuesday. A spokesperson for the county’s public schools did not immediately return a request for comment.

column4: Abercrombie expects redesigned stores to boost 2019 sales, shares surge
column5: (This March 6 story, corrects paragraph 2 to say company will be closing up to 40 stores, not 40 stores; also drops reference to on-trend clothing boosting demand for the Abercrombie brand)
column6: (Reuters) - Abercrombie & Fitch’s shares surged 20 percent after the apparel retailer forecast better-than-expected annual sales on Wednesday, betting on its remodeled stores and the popularity of its Hollister brand to attract more young shoppers.
column7: The company also said it would close up to 40 stores, and improve the store experience that in the past has included better lighting and displays in stores.
column8: Chief Executive Fran Horowitz said stores with a new format are proving to be “highly productive” and the company would continue to invest in them.
column9: “We are one of the specialty retailers still committed to investing in physical space,” she said.
column10: The company’s Abercrombie brand has been fighting falling sales as young shoppers shunned its trademark logo-emblazoned designs for fast-fashion brands and cheaper clothes online.
column11: Same-store sales at the Abercrombie brand fell 2 percent in the fourth quarter and the company blamed it on fashion missteps in tops and dresses during the holidays.
column12: Hollister, by contrast, reported a 6 percent rise in same-store sales.
column13: The company had gotten the silhouette wrong for Abercrombie tops and dresses, which were different from the fitted and oversized styles that shoppers were looking for, said Gabriela Santaniello of retail research firm A line Partners.
column14: “They’ve corrected it ... people were worried that this was going to continue, it is clear that it was just a one-season thing,” she said.
column15: Abercrombie is investing in its loyalty program and using social media influencers to promote its new products including its “Fierce” perfume with brand-specific hashtags.
column16: Overall, sales at Abercrombie & Fitch stores open for at least a year rose 3 percent in the fourth quarter ended Feb. 2, about twice the 1.47 percent increase analysts had expected, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.
column17: Excluding one-time items, the company earned $1.35 per share, well above expectations of $1.15.
column18: For 2019, the company expects net sales of between $3.66 billion and $3.73 billion, well above estimates of $3.61 billion.

column4: Abercrombie & Fitch tops Wall St sales forecasts
column5: March 6 (Reuters) - Abercrombie & Fitch beat Wall Street forecasts for quarterly same-store sales on Wednesday, as the clothing retailer sold more Hollister apparel during the holidays.
column6: In the fourth quarter ended Feb. 2, sales at its stores open at least a year rose 3 percent, above analysts’ average estimate of a 1.47 percent increase, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.
column7: Net sales fell 3.1 percent to $1.16 billion, but edged past the $1.13 billion Wall Street had expected. (Reporting by Nivedita Balu in Bengaluru; Editing by Sai Sachin Ravikumar)

column4: Abercrombie & Fitch forecasts upbeat holiday quarter, shares soar
column5: (Reuters) - U.S. teen apparel retailer Abercrombie & Fitch Co ANF.N forecast same-store sales for the holiday quarter above analysts' estimates on Thursday, driven by strong sales at its Hollister and flagship stores, sending its shares soaring 24 percent in early trading.
column6: “We saw a solid start to the holiday season in November, with strong double-digit growth on Singles Day on Tmall, and a record performance over the peak Holiday period from Thanksgiving Day through Cyber Monday,” Chief Executive Officer Fran Horowitz said on a call with investors.
column7: Tmall is Alibaba’s BABA.N giant online marketplace.
column8: Horowitz emphasized the steep investments the company has made in better managing its supply chain and product assortment to serve customers faster.
column9: Abercrombie has changed its namesake fashion brand in recent years, doing away with risque advertising and logo-emblazoned apparel, which fell out of fashion in the late 2000s. It has relied on Hollister to generate the majority of its revenue as its denim and Gilly Hicks intimates collections prove to be a hit with younger customers.
column10: The New Albany, Ohio-based retailer now expects to close fewer stores in the current year based on improved performance and successful lease renegotiations. It anticipates closing up to 40 stores by year-end, primarily in the United States, down from its previous expectation of closing up to 60 stores.
column11: Ken Perkins, founder of research firm Retail Metrics, said the company was well-positioned for a strong holiday but Abercrombie’s namesake brand has some work to do to resonate with shoppers.
column12: The company promoted the head of Hollister, Kristin Scott, to a newly created position of Global Brands president. Stacia Andersen, brand president of Abercrombie & Fitch, would be leaving the company, it said.
column13: The apparel retailer said it expected fourth-quarter same store sales to rise in the low single digits. Analysts had expected an increase of 0.6 percent.
column14: Sales at established stores rose 3 percent in the third quarter ended Nov. 3, well above an increase of 1.6 percent estimated by analysts, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.
column15: Net income rose to $23.9 million, or 35 cents per share, from $10.1 million, or 15 cents per share, a year earlier.
column16: Excluding one-time items, the company earned 33 cents per share, while net sales rose 0.2 percent to $861.2 mln.
column17: Analysts, on average, expected adjusted earnings of 20 cents per share on revenue of $853 million.

column4: Abercrombie & Fitch beats quarterly same-store sales estimates
column5: Nov 29 (Reuters) - Apparel retailer Abercrombie & Fitch Co topped quarterly same-store sales estimates on Thursday, driven by higher sales at its Hollister and flagship stores.
column6: The company said sales at established stores rose 3 percent in the third quarter ended Nov. 3. Analysts on average had expected a 1.6 percent increase, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.
column7: Net income attributable to Abercrombie rose to $23.9 million, or 35 cents per share, from $10.1 million, or 15 cents per share, a year earlier. (Reporting by Uday Sampath in Bengaluru; Editing by Anil D’Silva)

column4: Abercrombie sales miss as Hollister runs out of stock in Europe
column5: (Reuters) - Abercrombie & Fitch Co ANF.N failed to take full advantage of an unusually long summer in Europe as its stock of Hollister brand of summerwear could not keep up with increased demand in the second quarter, sending its shares down as much as 14.6 percent.
column6: The company’s quarterly same-store sales missed Wall Street estimates on Thursday, taking the shine off a surprise adjusted profit.
column7: “We sold through our warm wear seasonal categories too quickly and frankly ran out of ammunition as we moved through the quarter and the weather turned much warmer for much longer,” Chief Operating Officer Joanne Crevoiserat said on a conference call. “We overreacted to slower selling coming out of the first quarter.”
column8: Same-store sales of Hollister, the company’s key revenue contributor, rose 4 percent in the second quarter, but missed the analyst average estimate of 5.3 percent rise.
column9: In the current quarter, the company has made adjustments to its inventory to better suit the seasonal consumer tastes in Europe, Chief Executive Fran Horowitz said.
column10: The company said sales at established stores rose 3 percent in the quarter. Analysts on average had expected 3.7 percent increase, according to Thomson Reuters I/B/E/S.
column11: Given the strong sales coming out of peers such as American Eagle Outfitters AEO.N and Urban Outfitters URBN.O, Abercrombie's comparable sales will likely not be enough for investors, RBC Capital Markets analyst Brian Tunick said.
column12: Its flagship Abercrombie brand also missed analysts’ estimates for the quarter, raising concerns the segment’s recovery is stills on shaky ground.
column13: Abercrombie, which helped define teenage fashion before the turn of the millennium with its risque advertising and logo emblazoned apparel, fell out of trend in the late 2000s as other fast fashion companies gained popularity.
column14: The company has since tried to re-brand its namesake fashion brand by doing away with showcasing topless male models in stores and instead making advertisements that cater to a more diverse audience.
column15: Net loss attributable to Abercrombie narrowed to $3.9 million, or 6 cents per share, in the second quarter ended Aug. 4.
column16: Excluding one-time items, the company earned 6 cents per share, while analysts had expected a loss of 4 cents.
column17: The company’s net sales rose 8.1 percent to $842.4 million. Analysts on average had expected revenue of $845.2 million.

column4: Abercrombie & Fitch misses same-store sales estimates
column5: Aug 30 (Reuters) - Apparel retailer Abercrombie & Fitch Co missed quarterly same-store sales estimates on Thursday, hurt by lower-than-expected sales at its namesake line of teenage apparel and Hollister brand of surfwear.
column6: The company said sales at established stores rose 3 percent in the quarter. Analysts on average had expected 3.7 percent increase, according to Thomson Reuters I/B/E/S.
column7: Net loss attributable to Abercrombie narrowed to $3.9 million, or 6 cents per share, in the second quarter ended Aug. 4, from $15.5 million, or 23 cents per share, a year earlier.
column8: The company’s net sales rose to $842.4 million from $779.3 million.

column4: Abercrombie says turnaround not attracting enough shoppers to International flagship A&F stores
column5: (Reuters) - Abercrombie & Fitch Co ANF.N shares fell 9 percent on Friday after the apparel company suggested customer visits to its international flagship A&F stores were still not up to the mark despite its best efforts to turn the brand around.
column6: The Abercrombie brand has seen higher demand this year after struggling for the past five years, as the company revamped stores, launched sophisticated designs and scrapped its famously risqué advertisements.
column7: “We’ve done a couple of things, including rolling out our loyalty programs and investing in (Abercrombie International flagship) stores to improve conversion, and we have seen benefits there,” Chief Operating Officer Joanne Crevoiserat said on a conference call with analysts.
column8: “However, they have not been able to offset the headwinds we’re seeing in traffic,” she said.
column9: The remarks followed better-than-expected first-quarter results from the New Albany, Ohio-based retailer.
column10: Both the Abercrombie and Hollister brands topped Wall Street expectations for same-store sales, while the company’s overall sales rose 11 percent and its net loss was much smaller than expected.
column11: “If you look at the fundamentals and you look at the financial results, they were better than expected and that’s the bottom line,” said BlueFin Research analyst Rebecca Duval.
column12: Deutsche Bank analyst Tiffany Kanaga said results still fell well below the lofty expectations of some investors, triggering Friday’s sell-off in Abercrombie’s shares.
column13: The stock, which has rallied some 37 percent this year, fell 8.3 percent to $21.86 in afternoon trading.
column14: Investors were looking for a high-single percentage digit increase in same-store sales, Kanaga said. Abercrombie’s overall same-store sales rose 5 percent in the three months ended May 5.
column15: The results also come a day after Abercrombie & Fitch Chief Executive Officer Fran Horowitz told Bloomberg in an interview that the threat of retaliatory tariffs on U.S. goods could be “one more thing to lose sleep on in this industry.”
column16: The Donald Trump administration on Friday imposed tariffs on steel and aluminum from Canada, Mexico and Europe on Thursday.
column17: Abercrombie and fellow apparel company Levi Strauss were concerned ahead of threatened tit-for-tat tariffs from the EU, Canada and Mexico on U.S. goods such as jeans, Harley-Davidson motorcycles and bourbon, Bloomberg reported.
column18: “It could be the tariff situation that is concerning the investors ... Obviously apparel retailers could be ultimately be affected because they import virtually everything,” said Ken Perkins, founder of research firm Retail Metrics.
column19: (This version of the story has been corrected to “international flagship A&F stores” from “flagship A&F stores” in headline and first paragraph; also corrects attribution of quote in third paragraph to chief operating officer from chief financial officer)

column4: Abercrombie & Fitch tops same-store sales estimates
column5: June 1 (Reuters) - Apparel retailer Abercrombie & Fitch Co topped Wall Street forecasts for quarterly same-store sales on Friday, led by stronger demand for Hollister surfwear as well as its namesake teen apparel line.
column6: The company said sales at established stores rose 5 percent in the first quarter ended May 5. Analysts on average had expected a 4 percent increase, according to Thomson Reuters I/B/E/S.
column7: Net sales rose to $730.9 million from $661.1 million. (Reporting by Uday Sampath in Bengaluru; Editing by Sai Sachin Ravikumar)
